stem: Which assessment finding requires the MOST immediate intervention by the nurse?

itemContext.sbar: The patient is a 6-year-old male admitted for acute asthma exacerbation. He has received one nebulized albuterol treatment in the ED. He is currently restless and anxious.

rationale.correct: The patient's low oxygen saturation (90% on room air) coupled with an elevated PaCO2 (50 mmHg) indicates significant respiratory compromise and impending respiratory failure. This requires immediate intervention to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
rationale.incorrect: While the other findings are concerning, they do not represent the same level of immediate threat to the patient's life as the desaturation and elevated PaCO2.
clinicalPearls: In pediatric asthma exacerbations, changes in mental status (restlessness, anxiety) can be early signs of hypoxia.
A PaCO2 within normal limits during an asthma exacerbation can be a sign of impending respiratory failure, as the patient is tiring and unable to maintain adequate ventilation.
Persistent wheezing, even after bronchodilator treatment, indicates ongoing airway obstruction.

questionTrap.commonMistake: Focusing solely on the wheezing and not recognizing the significance of the ABG results and oxygen saturation.
questionTrap.reason: Students may be drawn to the wheezing because it is a classic sign of asthma. However, it's crucial to prioritize the most critical physiological parameters.

mnemonic.name: ABCs of Asthma
mnemonic.description: Airway (patency, work of breathing), Breathing (rate, depth, oxygen saturation, ABGs), Circulation (heart rate, blood pressure, perfusion), Consciousness (mental status).

options.text: Audible wheezing throughout all lung fields.
Oxygen saturation of 90% on room air with PaCO2 of 50 mmHg.
